page.title: 06 STOKE CLUMP
page.content: A natural, privately-owned landmark, 400 feet above sea level, about one mile north of{West Stoke, West Sussex. Beech trees at the summit were originally planted by the{Duke of {Richmond}in l707-08, to commemorate a {Peninsular War}victory. Many old trees have fallen; and extensive replanting has been done in recent years. The surrounding fields are used for{wheat, {dairy}and{sheep}farming. The plantation on top is now used as cover for{pheasant-rearing.}The summit is still used as a{sighting-marker}by boats entering{Chichester Harbour}to the S.W., enabling them to avoid the dangerous sands at{East Head.}Current hedge-dating techniques indicate a pattern of enclosure in surrounding land dating from approx. the l5th.century
